body:
Great! :+1: 

I guess we'll cache dependencies, personally I always cache dependencies for the CI on my own repo, and I never ran into issues or bugs, maybe I'm lucky enough, and I've got faster CI.

> I think using caching without having a package-lock.json file is going to cause problems sooner or later...

I don't see anywhere in the docs, that we should not cache dependencies without `package-lock.json`.

That's another discussion not directly related to this PR but in my opinion, if we everyone could use exact version in their `package.json` and we didn't invented version match with `^` or `~` etc symbol, we would have less problems.
In my own repo even if it's not an npm package, I only use `package.json` and ignore `lockfiles` so it works with whatever package manager `npm`, `yarn`, `pnpm`, etc, and we don't need to manage a big ugly `package-lock.json` file, also in `git` we should avoid to commit generated files, as we do for build.

> This will also have the added benefit of making the build reproducible.

That's right, but if every packages would use exact version match, we would not need to use `package-lock.json`, I know that's not the case unfortunately.
